title: Tesla owners warned to charge their cars as planned power outage hits California
text:
The Pacific Gas & Electric Company (PG&E), California’s largest utility, cut power for wide swathes of California on Wednesday; it isn’t expected to be restored until Friday or later. The firm is attempting to prevent wildfires caused by damaged equipment stemming from high seasonal winds. (CNN)

Talking point: Earlier this year, officials determined that PG&E equipment was to blame for California’s deadliest wildfire, which killed 86 people and torched 150,000 acres of land last November. The utility is still grappling with nearly US$50 billion in liabilities and thousands of lawsuits from that event, which is likely what’s spurred this unprecedented preemptive move. The San Francisco Bay Area, among the places affected by the outages, is one of America’s most wired regions, and California is the country’s biggest electric car market. Tesla issued an official warning to customers, instructing them to charge their cars to 100 per cent to prepare for the outages. The blackouts aren’t hitting everybody in the area equally—the headquarters of almost every major tech giant in the region are unaffected, since they’re largely served by bulky high-voltage transmission lines that are less vulnerable to the weather.
